author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum opens in 1959
text:
Mayor Wagner snips tape during dedication of the Guggenheim Museum, the nation's most unique art gallery, on Fifth Ave. at 88th Street in 1959. (Originally published by the Daily News on October 22, 1959.)
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum at Fifth Ave. and 88th St., the only major structure in the city designed by the late architect Frank Lloyd Wright was dedicated yesterday and opened to the public.
The controversial circular, six-story concrete housing for the Guggenheim collection of paintings and sculpture and its designer were highly praised by speakers at the dedication which was attended by some 300 persons.
Hailed by Lodge
Henry Cabot Lodge U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, described the building as "only possible in a free democracy."
Harry F. Guggenheim, nephew of the museum founder and chairman of the museum board, said the building, which was described by critics as "a corkscrew" and "a washing machine," was "not only an evolution but a revolution and again demonstrates Mr. Wright's genius."
New York Daily News The New York Daily News published this article on Oct. 22, 1959. "Youthful Spirit"
Mayor Wagner called it a "unique addition to our concrete skyline." Robert Moses said the design was "evidence that Mr. Wright's youthful and creative spirit will always live."
A letter from President Eisenhower, which did not refer to the design, said that "this museum is a symbol of our free society."
More than 1,500 persons inspected the museum when the doors were opened at 2 P.M. They climbed the spiraled interior walks to view the art collections on four floors. The upper two floors were closed off.
